hi: i am having trouble running gpg --keyserver
and what's the error that you get?
aha... well, chmod that gpg.conf file to 600
or hell, chmod the whole .gnupg dir to 600.
aha, so the stuff is owned by root... that's the problem.
then, you need to run "sudo chown -R yourusername:yourusername ~/.gnupg"
to restore the ownership of the files back to you
replace "yourusername" with your actual username, of course
still getting the same error? and... whats ls -al showing on the .gnupg dir? who owns the files (and the dir), and what are the permissions?
change permissions on the .gnupg directory itself. make it 700. "chmod 700 ~/.gnupg"
